name: sfchronicle
text:
102 years ago, on Nov. 21, 1918, San Franciscans tired of the Spanish flu threw off their masks. 

The flu roared back in January, nearly doubling the death toll, and taking advantage of a city that had completely let down its guard.

https://t.co/TFJLbsSi7e

name: sfchronicle
text: Many people who test positive for the virus in San Francisco aren‚Äôt sure how they got it, and the city‚Äôs contact tracing team often can‚Äôt help them figure it out. https://t.co/AUKHGwzOTn

name: sfchronicle
text:
San Mateo County reported the highest number of daily new coronavirus cases since the pandemic's start. 

The 215 cases reported Saturday eclipse the county‚Äôs previous high of 208 on Aug. 10, according to data from The Chronicle‚Äôs coronavirus tracker.

name: sfchronicle
text:
Georgia senator Kelly Loeffler tested positive for the coronavirus but awaits more results. She was "maskless with Vice President Mike Pence and Sen. David Perdue during campaign events," CNN reports. Loeffler faces a run-off election in Georgia.

name: sfchronicle
text:
Update: The six-alarm fire burning on University Ave. in Berkeley was contained to the original building where it started, but it continued to burn and will likely smolder overnight, fire officials said.

A cause of the fire has not yet been determined.

https://t.co/CEW43GjQ76

name: sfchronicle
text:
San Francisco celebrated the end of the Spanish flu in 1918, throwing masks in the street when the threat was far from over. Then flu roared back in January.
https://t.co/keS9FGR0BS

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @KateGalbraith: Days before Thanksgiving in 1918, San Franciscans threw their masks in the street against the wishes of the health department and celebrated the end of the "Spanish flu" epidemic. That didn't go so well, as my colleague @peterhartlaub has written: https://t.co/9iVjT5DU32
